channel.title: SaveOurPrivacy on Internet Freedom Foundation
channel.description: Recent content in SaveOurPrivacy on Internet Freedom Foundation

item.title: MEITY filed a limited affidavit in Supreme Court without confirming or denying if the Government used Pegasus
item.description: The Government has filed a limited affidavit before the SC which proposes to constitute a Committee of Experts but does not categorically comment on whether the government used the Pegasus Spyware. The SC has heard submissions on the limited affidavit and has listed the case for 17.08.2021.

item.title: Securing Examination Data: No Child’s Play
item.description: Concerned about the threat to children’s privacy and safety caused by such data breaches, in July 2021, IFF sent thirty-two representations to the State and Union Territory Commissions for the Protection of Child Rights in India.

item.title: ClubHouse: How safe really is this 'safe space'?
item.description: In this post, we unfurl some of the key considerations Clubhouse must include while fostering a robust human rights framework for its rapidly growing millions of users.

item.title: Hyderabad Police force people to remove their masks before photographing them. We sent a legal notice. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Hyderabad Police is forcing people to remove masks and photographing them. We sent a legal notice to the Police Commissioner about this.

item.title: Cybersec Charcha: Understanding the booming ransomware industry
item.description: In the second edition of Cybersec Charcha, we are taking a deep dive into understanding the unregulated ransomware industry, what a ransomware attack means and the consequences it can have.

item.title: Despite CIC’s observation that MeitY's response to us was “grossly improper," MeitY issues the same response again #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: CIC directed the CPIO to re-visit our original RTI and provide a revised reply and info, if (comments on consultation on PDPB). However, the CPIO simply cited the same exemption under S.8 of the RTI Act that she had provided before the CIC.

item.title: The Delhi Govt. is using facial recognition on children in Govt. schools #ProjectPanoptic
item.description: We wrote to the Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights (DCPCR) urging them to step in to protect child rights in Delhi against use of harmful facial recognition technology in schools.

item.title: Sustained, strategic litigation helps advance transparency in digital policymaking #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Updates from the High Court of Delhi on the writ petition of Saurav Das who is challenging the Central Information Commission’s order denying him information on Aarogya Setu.

item.title: Breach please! Why companies like Facebook need to be held accountable by CERT-IN.
item.description: Personal data of 60 Lakh Indian Facebook users is available on the internet for free. We provide suggestions on what you can do and we update you on the steps we have taken.

item.title: #StartFromScratch: An Explainer on the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019
item.description: Part 2 of our series on the data bill will explain the basics of the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019. In it, we provide an introduction to the main definitions, the Data Processing Authority is, user rights, and exemptions provided to the government.

item.title: #ElectionFever: What do party manifestos have in store for tech and digital rights?
item.description: With state elections incoming, we thought we would do our bit for #electionfever by analysing the manifestos of political parties across the spectrum. Our analysis is guided by our focus areas and is meant to help voters understand how political parties are looking at these issues.

item.title: Hindsight is 20/20: Assessing outcomes from Aarogya Setu
item.description: We are close to a year since the launch of Arogya Setu. This is why we have written to the National Informatics Centre, pointing out that issues with Aarogya Setu have still not been addressed.

item.title: DNA Bill : On democratic processes and dystopian outcomes #IFFExplainer #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Standing Committee on Science and Technology recently submitted its report on the DNA Bill. Several concerns have been raised over the report, with two Committee members filing dissent notes. We decided to provide an explainer that breaks down the key issues with both the report and the Bill.

item.title: A rose by any other name? CBSE's face matching technology is just facial recognition in disguise
item.description: Read our representation to CBSE highlighting the concerns that come along with the use of facial recognition technology which they have put in place for accessing digital documents.

item.title: We wrote to the UGC and the Ministry of Education on exam proctoring
item.description: Following multiple reports of the use of exam proctoring technology by various universities across the country, we wrote to the University Grants Commission and the Ministry of Education.

item.title: Ensuring security and the protection of privacy in data centres
item.description: IFF has sent its comments to the MEITY on the Draft Data Centre Policy. In our comments we highlighted four issues we feel the policy must address: adequate security standards, safeguards for user privacy, firm regulatory oversight, and the unecessary imposition of ESMA.

item.title: Watch the Watchmen Series Part 5 : The Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019
item.description: In the fifth part of our “Watch the Watchmen” series, we take a closer look at PDP Bill which is likely to be tabled in next year’s Budget Session.

item.title: Watch the Watchmen Series Part 4 : The National Automated Facial Recognition System
item.description: In the fourth part of our “Watch the Watchmen” series which aims to develop and use a national database of photographs which is to be used in conjunction with a facial recognition technology system by Central and State security agencies to swiftly identify criminals.

item.title: Move fast, break things? Not when sensitive health data is at stake! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the National Health Authority seeking enactment of general and sectoral data protection laws and meaningful public consultation prior to deployment of any national digital health ID programme.

item.title: Let's bring academics, experts and civil society to the table! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Personal Data Protection Bill (PDP) 2019, which is critical for the data privacy, is being considered by a special Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) and it must invite independent experts and civil society organisations for depositions.

item.title: Four months on, Aarogya Setu is still not open-source. WHY and WHEN is what the nation really wants to know! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Four months, after its initial release, the Aarogya Setu app is not open-source in the true sense of the term. Source code releases have been slow and incomplete. This is preventing the Indian tech community from collaborating and contributing.

item.title: IFF's Legal Notice to the NCRB on the Revised RFP for the National Automated Facial Recognition System #ProjectPanoptic
item.description: IFF has sent the NCRB a legal notice asking them to recall the revised RFP for AFRS citing concerns of violations of fundamental rights of privacy and freedom of speech and expression.

item.title: Is the illegal use of facial recognition technology by the Delhi Police akin to mass surveillance? You decide. #Project Panoptic
item.description: In this blogpost, we collate and analyze our findings on the Delhi Police’s use of facial recognition technology. Use of facial recognition without having a legal framework in place to regulate it raises the threat of mass surveillance.

item.title: Bulk data sharing policy scrapped is an incremental victory that requires follow up action #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The MoRTH has scrapped its Bulk Data Sharing Policy. While this is a great step, there are a few critical privacy loopholes that still remain to be addressed. We wrote to the ministry identifying as well providing recommendations to tackle these loopholes.

item.title: How (cyber)safe are the Indian citizens? Think again and think harder. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Committee on IT, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha, and the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha. We highlighted the presence of massive cybersecurity threats in India and the need for reinstating parliamentary deliberation for protecting citizens' rights.

item.title: The ongoing illegal use of drones for mass surveillance by the Delhi Police needs to be investigated #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the MCA and DGCA asking them to recall the conditional exemption allowing the use of drones for COVID-19 related operations and to commence an investigation into the ongoing illegal use of drones by the Delhi Police for mass surveillance.

item.title: The Committee on IT is meeting next week! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Committee on IT is meeting on June 10, 2020 to discuss the issue of, “Citizens data security and privacy”. We are hopeful it puts questions on Aarogya Setu and Data Breaches to the Ministry of IT.

item.title: It's time to stop data breaches and security vulnerabilities. We write to the IT Ministry. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Till we fix the regulatory and cyber security plumbing of our digital, public infrastructure the data leaks and cyber security vulnerabilities will continue

item.title: A look at Aarogya Setu through the Right to Information lens #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF has filed multiple Right to Information requests with various governmental authorities on the Aarogya Setu application. In this post, we will highlight these requests, the substantial replies that we received as well as the non-answers which also tell us a lot.

item.title: We wrote to the Kerala Government and the Expert Committee formed on the Sprinklr Inc. Data Protection issue in Kerala highlighting the need for preserving the ideal of Constitutional Federalism #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: In our representation to the Government of Kerala and the Expert Committee formed on the issue, we have pointed out certain lacunae in the Kerala HC order addressing the issue and have made specific suggestions on how best to resolve them.

item.title: Committee on IT : Get up! Stand up, for our privacy rights! #AarogyaSetu #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Standing Committee for Information Technology to hold hearings on Aarogya Setu.

item.title: We wrote to NCRB and MHA requesting them to halt their ongoing National Automated Facial Recognition System (AFRS) project #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We have shared a representation with the NCRB and the Hon’ble Minister of Home Affairs Mr Amit Shah highlighting the legal and constitutional issues with their National Automated Facial Recognition System (AFRS) project.

item.title: Unpacking the positives and risks of Apple and Google’s contact tracing foray #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF’s Working Paper on Privacy Prescriptions for Technology Interventions on COVID-19 in India, affords significant space to the issue of contact tracing technologies. It offers a preliminary breakdown of the Apple and Google’s proposed partnership to provide a digital contact tracing solution.

item.title: Is Aarogya Setu privacy-first? Nope, but it could be-- If the government wanted. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF’s Working Paper, analyses the Aarogya Setu application, highlights how it is inconsistent with the right to privacy, is conceivably a risk toward a permanent system of mass surveillance, and suggests clear recommendations to arrest these risks.

item.title: A comprehensive look at Covid Surveillance and Privacy in India #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF has authored a comprehensive working paper to inform public policy formation in India, including a substantive analysis of the use and publication of health data, specific development of surveillance technologies and deployment of contact tracing through device applications.

item.title: The need to investigate the NSO Group, which was behind the Pegasus software, is now more than ever. #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We wrote to the Chief Ministers of Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh urging them to establish committees to investigate the Whatsapp hack. Our key recommendations were to include victim and expert testimony in the investigation which should be carried out in a transparent manner.

item.title: Quarantine lists breach individual privacy! Social solidarity in times of Covid-19 #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: We have written to the Government to issue advisories against lists of persons who are suspected or potentially infected with Covid-19 from being circulated on social media and WhatsApp groups.

item.title: Essential Features of a Rights Respecting Data Protection Law #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF has made a submission to the Joint Committee on the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019

item.title: Women deserve both privacy and safety
item.description: The WCD Ministry has approved use of the Nirbhaya Fund for large scale installation of CCTV cameras. This kind of mass video surveillance without adequate safeguards is likely to be ineffective and counterproductive.

item.title: Educate and advocate for better privacy protection before the Data Protection JPC
item.description: Read SaveOurPrivacy.in’s analysis of the PDP Bill, 2019. This helps you form your views and participate in the invitation to public comments invited by the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

item.title: It's the final countdown (kinda) on the Data Protection Bill #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Joint parliamentary committee invites evidence on the Data Protection Bill, 2019.

item.title: The Delhi Police must stop it's facial recognition system
item.description: We wrote to the Delhi Police demanding a complete halt and recall of Automated Facial Recognition System.

item.title: The DGCA must take urgent action against the illegal use of surveillance drones.
item.description: We wrote to the Office of the Director General of Civil Aviation urging for urgent action against police departments using illegal drones.

item.title: Statement: Scary disclosures on use of NSO spyware in India signal a need for urgent reform
item.description: News reports have revealed the targeting of lawyers, journalists and activists in India through NSO’s illegal spyware, Pegasus. While these revelations have left many of us shaken, we must demand transparency from the govt and push for surveillance reform in parliament and courts.

item.title: #PrivacySupreme: Two years of the Right to Privacy.
item.description: 24 August 2019 marks the second anniversary of the Indian Supreme Court’s landmark judgement in KS Puttaswamy v. Union of India. We celebrate and critically appraise this moment as we discuss our next steps in protecting the Right to Privacy.

item.title: Personal Data and Information Privacy Code Bill, 2019 introduced in the Lok Sabha today! #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: IFF goes to Parliament with Dr. Ravikumar (Lok Sabha, MP from Tamil Nadu). Today, the Personal Data and Information Privacy Code Bill, 2019 was introduced!

item.title: He sees you when you're sleeping, He knows when you're awake, He gets your personal data and sells it for your own sake. #DystopiaBells
item.description: We write to the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology enquiring on the status of the Draft Data Protection Bill. The need for a rights-based framework has never been more immediate.

item.title: The Madras HC allows our intervention in the Aadhaar and Social Medial linking petition.
item.description: Two PILs were filed in the Madras High Court requesting the linking of Aadhaar to social media accounts. Concerned with its impact on fundamental rights, IFF’s intervention applications have been accepted by the Court.

item.title: The purpose of 'Public' in 'Public Consultation', lest we merely consult.
item.description: The Draft Personal Data Protection Bill was first put up for public consultation in August 2018. While there have been many responses, these submissions have not been made public. This lack of transparency is a cause for concern as the Bill moves to Parliament.

item.title: And we can't stop, and we won't stop #SaveOurPrivacy continues...
item.description: This budget session of parliament is super important to your privacy. Read on to understand how #SaveOurPrivacy is fighting hard to advance your rights!

item.title: We won’t give up! IFF approaches CIC against MHA’s refusal to disclose surveillance figures.
item.description: After the MHA rejected our RTI applications about use of surveillance powers on flimsy grounds, IFF has filed an appeal before the CIC and we are willing to go the distance in this fight for transparency.

item.title: IFF files rejoinder in PIL seeking surveillance reform
item.description: Yesterday, IFF filed its rejoinder in the PIL seeking surveillance reform and reemphasized that judicial oversight is necessary in the surveillance process.

item.title: An alternative to bans. A Letter to MEITY.
item.description: In a letter written to MEITY, IFF reasons the need for alternative measures to addressing the safety of minors instead of resorting to disproportionate bans.

item.title: Statement on the TikTok Ban
item.description: We are in the process of conferring with legal counsel and will be taking steps to ensure that the fundamental rights of internet users are considered by the Hon’ble Court. As with all of IFF’s work, subsequent steps and updates will be informed regularly and transparently.

item.title: Secret Operating Procedure for digital snooping revealed. Confirms fears of centralisation of executive power, zero judicial scrutiny and oversight.
item.description: The Secret Operating Procedure for conducting digital surveillance has been produced by the MHA before the Supreme Court for the first time. The document worryingly reveals lack of any judicial oversight and dilution of existing safeguards.

item.title: We call on MEITY in our counter comments to withdraw the proposed changes to the Intermediary rules. They are unconstitutional and open to legal challenge. #ITRules #SaveOurPrivacy #RightToMeme
item.description: The draft Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines) Rules, 2018 must be recalled. They are unconstitutional and against the fundamental rights of privacy and free speech of Indians.

item.title: Protect your business. Protect your users. #ITRules #SaveOurPrivacy #RightToMeme
item.description: We call on tech start-ups to press for a recall of the proposed changes to Intermediary Rules. #ITRules #SaveOurPrivacy #RightToMeme

item.title: Digital rights and research organisations are unanimous. Proposed changes to Intermediary Rules must be recalled. #ITRules #SaveOurPrivacy #RightToMeme
item.description: Do not let the Government weaken your privacy and censor you online. Take action today. Send them an email.

item.title: TOP SECRET: MHA Refuses to reveal total number of snooping requests
item.description: RTIs asking for basic information on surveillance in India rejected by the Ministry of Home Affairs. They even refuse to tell how many orders were issued by them.

item.title: We urge MEITY to press reboot on the Intermediary Rules #SaveOurPrivacy #RightToMeme
item.description: We urge MEITY to recall the Draft of “The Information Technology [Intermediary Guidelines (Amendment) Rules] 2018 and then start afresh.

item.title: Supreme Court issues notice on IFF's petition for surveillance reform #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear a case on the digital snooping powers of the government.

item.title: Tell us if your ISP is blocking any proxy websites or VPNs. We promise to seek remedy. #SaveTheInternet #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: Folks! Do report any blocking of proxy or VPNs by your ISP. This is a net neutrality violation and undermines your privacy.

item.title: India must resist the lure of the Chinese model of online surveillance and censorship #IntermediaryRules #RightToMeme #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: As reported in today’s front page story in the Indian Express, why is the government and large online platforms are privately discussing how to censor and break encryption of your social media and messaging. We explain…

item.title: Explainer: How the MHA notification is another step in making India into a survelliance state #SaveOurPrivacy
item.description: So has the government merely issued a routine notification empowering intelligence agencies to gather intelligence to prevent terrorism or is this the creation of a surveillance state?
